snippet: An Oregon Supreme Court ruling shifts the burden of proof to prosecutors to show that eyewitness identification is sufficiently reliable to be admissible as evidence at trial.
abstract: Editorial applauds Oregon Supreme Court ruling that shifts burden of proof to prosecutors to show that eyewitness identification is sufficiently reliable to be admissible as evidence at trial; contends that other states would be wise to follow Oregon's example.
lead_paragraph: An Oregon Supreme Court ruling shifts the burden of proof to prosecutors to show that eyewitness identification is sufficiently reliable to be admissible as evidence at trial.
